title: Great Britain's James Hall is the unflashy gymnast hoping to lead the team to medal glory in Stuttgart
text:
A good gymnastics team is like a boy band. The personnel must cover the six different instruments – from high bar to pommel horse – while showing off a range of moods: the sensitive one, the edgy one, the charismatic extrovert.

James Hall – a bone-dry 23-year-old from Maidstone – is the glue that holds the whole operation together. While the likes of Louis Smith and Nile Wilson love the spotlight, Hall prefers to lurk in the background, turning in precise and unflashy routines on at least five different pieces.

If he takes a medal at this week’s World Championships in Stuttgart, it will probably be in the all-around category, because, as Hall cheerfully admits: “I never really had any strong points as a youngster, I just kept plodding along.” What is more likely, though, is that he will anchor Great Britain in their search for a team medal, something the men have achieved only once (a silver in 2015) since the World Championships were launched in 1903.

In this role, Hall resembles the now-retired Kristian Thomas, who captained the British team in Rio and delivered a killer vault to grab team bronze at London 2012. Neither came up through the junior ranks with much fanfare but both turned into the most dependable of all-rounders.
description: A good gymnastics team is like a boy band.
